issues.title: Move section 4 to RFC4053bis
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: that section talks about consensus and transmission of liaison statements, however, this is not specific to LS where we have a formal liaison relationship. Therefore it should not be part of this document but RFC5043 instead.

issues.title: Explain that informal relationships are preferred
issues.author: sureshkrishnan
issues.body: There needs to be some text to document our current unwritten policy (needs to be rechecked for consensus) that informal relationships with other organizations are preferred over formal liaison relationships if they are sufficient. Section 2.4. talks a bit about this in the case of transmittal of liaison statements but this is a broader matter.

issues.title: Explain that liaisons have no special place in the IETF processes
issues.author: sureshkrishnan
issues.body: There needs to be text in the document that everyone is open to participate in the IETF: all the documents are freely available to everyone and any input/output going through the liaisons is really going through the same WG/IETF process as any other participants.

issues.title: Checklist for creation of relationships
issues.author: sureshkrishnan
issues.body: Work on some form of checklist with typical items that might require setting up a liaison relationship. In most cases this would be related to the other SDO's processes. e.g. Can the SDO's standards be freely accessed or does that require a liaison to access them, how can input be provided to their processes etc.

issues.title: Should we merge RFC4691 into RFC4052bis?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: RFC4691 (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4691) seems to actually duplicate quite some thing from RFC4052, there I think it would be more beneficial to merge them together. Especially section 3.4 and 3.5 of RFC4691 should be merged with section 3 and 4 of RFC4052, respectively. Also we chould add a more clear statement on " Speaking for the IETF" Section 3.1.1 of RFC4691 to RFC4052bis. But not sure if we need much from section 3.2 and 3.3 though.

issues.title: Do we still need the liaison representative role?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: This role exists in RFC4052 but I don't think we use it. I think it better to only have one decided responsible person. If that person is not available for some reason, the IAB or the IAB liaison coordinators should cover any urgent issues directly. If a liaison manager generally needs help, it might be sufficient to ask inofficially for support from a specific person for a specific topic but I don't think we need a formal process around this. Again, bottom line is we don't seem to use it.

comments.author: mirjak
comments.body: Agreed that we don't need anymore (at least not formatting in the RFC)

issues.title: Remove ISOC
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
RFC4052 says:

"the IAB acts as representative of the interests of the IETF and the Internet Society in technical liaison relationships with other organizations concerned with standards and other technical and organizational issues relevant to the worldwide Internet."

I don't think we should name ISOC here. Usually ISOC is not involved in any of these are liaisons are usually relationships between technical organisations.

issues.title: terminology: define and use "formal liaison relationship"?
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body: Usually the term "liaison" is quite loosely used. e.g. people might call a liaison statement a "liaison" or assume that there is something like a default liaison between all (technical orgs). We should clearly define that informal liaison relationships are fine when e.g. when formal liaison statements or any entirely information communication between groups. However, we only talk about a formal liaison relationship if on our side the IAB has appointed a liaison manager and on the other side there is some kind of agreement or process recognises this relationship (formally); this may include cases where the other org has also appointed a liaison manager but no other written agreement.

issues.title: Main responsibility of LM is good communication between orgs
issues.author: mirjak
issues.body:
Sec 3 lists responsibilities of LMs. There are effectively 6 points in random order. I think we should make it much more clear that the one main (and basically only real) responsibility is to manage a good communication between the orgs. This includes of course caring about LSs (make sure they are correctly formatted, are sent to the right place on both sides, and support people sending replies in time) but also any additional communication e.g. to communicate back informally e.g when no reply is sent or explain our process or redirect questions to the right place. This may of course require to go to the meeting in some form at least.

But I think especially the point about providing updates is more optional. Making the IAB aware of issues is part of the communication bit, but giving real updates on what's happening in the other org might not necessarily be possible as orgs like 3GPP and ITU-T are big and probably hard to follow by one person only. If the LM gives these updates it's a nice service but not a requirement on the job.

Also we have these IAB program which are usually lead by the LM and these activities can be seen as important for ensuring good communication, however, it doesn't necessarily have to be the LM that leads these program. I think it usually makes sense that way and this is also the way all these programs work right now but it could also be a different person, e.g. if a split of load is desired.

Further, it is not the responsibilities of the LM to change anything in the way liaison management works. If there is a problem, the IAB should be notified and the IAB need to address the problem (potentially of course with the help of the LM as the LM is the matter expert).

Also inline with RFC4691 we should make more clear that it is not the job of the manager to directly engage in technical discussions (rather than beginning the messenger or pointing people to existing consensus positions). Of course a LM can participate in any technical discussion in its personal capacity but the LM cannot speak for the IETF, nor has their voice any higher weight.

issues.title: Do we need to describe liaison relationships for IRTF
issues.author: sureshkrishnan
issues.body: There are liaisons that are received that might be relevant for research groups. Currently this is informally processed through the IRTF chair who is part of the IAB. Do we need to formalize this somehow in this document.
